elements.content: Two new isostructural 3D porous coordination polymers {[Ni2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·18H2O} n (1), {[Mn2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·3H2O} n (2) (DBIBA = 5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzoate) have been synthesized by acidic hydrolysis of cyanide functional group of 5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl) benzonitrile under solvothermal conditions. Both the compounds have been characterized by X-ray crystallography, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetry, powder X-ray diffraction, and elemental analysis. They form isoreticular structures with binodal 4,6-connected net having 1D hexagonal channels. These channels are occupied by water molecules. Frameworks are stabilized by hydrogen bonding interactions with anion and π–π interactions in the hexagonal cavity. Desolvated 1 exhibits selective CO2, while 2 shows N2, H2, and CO2 gas adsorption properties without any selectivity. This difference in gas adsorption properties is attributed to different degrees of flexibility of the framework. Magnetic susceptibility measurements at low temperature show weak ferromagnetic behavior in both coordination polymers 1 and 2 due to spin canting phenomenon. Complex {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·9H2O} n (3), which was previously reported by us, was also subjected to variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements.

Compound 1 is selective for CO2 gas sorption, while 2 shows adsorption for N2, H2, and CO2 gases. Magnetic susceptibility measurements show weak ferromagnetic behavior in both 1 and 2 at low temperature due to spin canting phenomenon.
elements.clean_text: Two isostructural 3D porous coordination polymers of Ni(II) and Mn(II) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compound 1 is selective for CO2 gas sorption, while 2 shows adsorption for N2, H2, and CO2 gases. Magnetic susceptibility measurements show weak ferromagnetic behavior in both 1 and 2 at low temperature due to spin canting phenomenon.

elements.content: Currently metal–organic frameworks are under intense investigation for a variety of potential applications like gas storage, gas separation, catalysis, etc., because of their high surface area and tunable pore sizes with added functionality. Particularly, adsorption of a gas inside the cavity of a porous coordination polymer (PCP) is of immense importance. The capture and separation of CO2 from other gases emitted from power plants is a daunting challenge. Up to now, a variety of PCPs with permanent porosity have been successfully synthesized. It has been observed that the gas adsorption is a dynamic phenomenon, which is not only dependent on the nature of the framework but also on kinetic diameter of the guest molecules. Therefore, kinetic diameter of the gas molecule to be adsorbed as well as that of the pore window of the host are two important parameters that govern gas adsorption characteristics by a PCP. In the case of flexible porous frameworks, however, the interaction between host and guest molecules could have self-tuning mechanisms to adjust the pore shape and size to achieve stability. Of course, porous framework materials that change their structures in response to external stimuli, such as heat or pressure, are potentially being used in switching, sensing, and information storage devices. A great number of coordination polymers showing ferromagnetic, antiferromagnetic, spin canting, metamagnetism, single chain magnetism, and spin-glass behavior have been reported. Different coordination modes of carboxylate groups (syn–syn, syn–anti, anti–anti) with paramagnetic metal centers give rise to a variety of structures affording systems to study structure and magnetic relationships. To understand the structural features that control exchange coupling between paramagnetic centers, a great deal of work is required because of the complexity of this relationship. We have focused on the synthesis of new PCPs using 5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl) benzonitrile (DBIBN) as a ligand that incorporates flexibility in the framework arising from the C–N single bond rotation. Herein, we report solvothermal synthesis of {[Ni2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·18H2O} n (1) and {[Mn2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·3H2O} n (2). Desolvated 1 shows highly selective adsorption–desorption of CO2 gas at low pressure, while 2 exhibits N2, H2, and CO2 gas adsorption under various conditions. Both 1 and 2 and previously reported {[Co2(DBIBA)3]·Cl·9H2O} n (3) are subjected to variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Currently metal-organic frameworks are under intense investigation for a variety of potential applications like gas storage, gas separation, catalysis, etc., because of their high surface area and tunable pore sizes with added functionality. Particularly, adsorption of a gas inside the cavity of a porous coordination polymer (PCP) is of immense importance. The capture and separation of CO2 from other gases emitted from power plants is a daunting challenge. Up to now, a variety of PCPs with permanent porosity have been successfully synthesized. It has been observed that the gas adsorption is a dynamic phenomenon, which is not only dependent on the nature of the framework but also on kinetic diameter of the guest molecules. Therefore, kinetic diameter of the gas molecule to be adsorbed as well as that of the pore window of the host are two important parameters that govern gas adsorption characteristics by a PCP. In the case of flexible porous frameworks, however, the interaction between host and guest molecules could have self-tuning mechanisms to adjust the pore shape and size to achieve stability. Of course, porous framework materials that change their structures in response to external stimuli, such as heat or pressure, are potentially being used in switching, sensing, and information storage devices. A great number of coordination polymers showing ferromagnetic, antiferromagnetic, spin canting, metamagnetism, single chain magnetism, and spin-glass behavior have been reported. Different coordination modes of carboxylate groups (syn-syn, syn-anti, anti-anti) with paramagnetic metal centers give rise to a variety of structures affording systems to study structure and magnetic relationships. To understand the structural features that control exchange coupling between paramagnetic centers, a great deal of work is required because of the complexity of this relationship. We have focused on the synthesis of new PCPs using 5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl) benzonitrile (DBIBN) as a ligand that incorporates flexibility in the framework arising from the C-N single bond rotation. Herein, we report solvothermal synthesis of {[Ni2(DBIBA)3]⋅Cl⋅18H2O} n  (1) and {[Mn2(DBIBA)3]⋅Cl⋅3H2O} n  (2). Desolvated 1 shows highly selective adsorption-desorption of CO2 gas at low pressure, while 2 exhibits N2, H2, and CO2 gas adsorption under various conditions. Both 1 and 2 and previously reported {[Co2(DBIBA)3]⋅Cl⋅9H2O} n  (3) are subjected to variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements.

elements.content: Reagent grade 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were acquired from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, benzimidazole, and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. Solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Reagent grade 3,5-difluorobenzonitrile and metal salts were acquired from Aldrich and used as received. All solvents, benzimidazole, and K2CO3 were procured from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India. Solvents were purified prior to use following standard procedures.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) using a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in CDCl3 and DMSO-d 6, respectively, with Me4Si as the internal standard. ESI mass spectra were recorded using a WATERS Q-TOF premier mass spectrometer. TGA were recorded using a Mettler Toledo (heating rate of 10 °C/min) TGA instrument. Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Rigaku Rint 2000 X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment. Prior to BET adsorption measurements, the complexes 1 and 2 were immersed in dichloromethane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM after which it was heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) using a Perkin-Elmer model 1320 spectrometer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded using a JEOL-ECX 500 FT (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument in CDCl3 and DMSO-d 6, respectively, with Me4Si as the internal standard. ESI mass spectra were recorded using a WATERS Q-TOF premier mass spectrometer. TGA were recorded using a Mettler Toledo (heating rate of 10 °C/min) TGA instrument. Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using a CE-440 elemental analyzer (Exeter Analytical Inc.). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using a Rigaku Rint 2000 X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation. Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment. Prior to BET adsorption measurements, the complexes 1 and 2 were immersed in dichloromethane (DCM) for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM after which it was heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove solvent molecules.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were carried out in the Unitat de Mesures Magnetiques (Universitat de Barcelona) on polycrystalline samples (ca. 30 mg) with a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS-XL magnetometer equipped with a 5 T magnet. Diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constant and an experimental correction factor for the sample holder was applied.

Synthesis of {[Ni<sub>2</sub>(DBIBA)<sub>3</sub>]·Cl·18H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.07 g, 0.24 mmol), DBIBN (0.04 g, 0.12 mmol), and conc. HCl (0.1 mL) in EtOH:H2O (3 mL, 2:1 v/v) were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then, it was allowed to cool to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. Needle-shaped green crystals of 1 were collected in ∼42% yield. The crystals were repeatedly washed with ethanol and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C63H75N12O24ClNi2: C, 49.22; H, 4.92; N, 10.93%. Found: C, 49.07; H, 4.35; N, 10.82%. IR (cm–1): 3394(m), 3141(w), 3074(w), 3000(w), 1650(m), 1598(s), 1503(s), 1474(m), 1451(w), 1401(s), 1372(m), 1307(m), 1292(m), 1242(s), 1222(w), 1172(w), 1148(w), 1107(w), 1011(w), 942(w), 910(w), 861(w), 795(w), 778(m), 765(m), 746(s), 724(m), 693(w), 649(w), 627(w), 613(w), 525(w), 439(w), 425(w) (Figure S1, ).

elements.content:
This complex was synthesized as previously reported.

Single Crystal X-ray Studies

Single crystal X-ray data on complexes 1–2 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) as described earlier. For 1 and 2, squeeze refinement have been performed using PLATON that shows 18 water molecules per formula weight for 1 and three water molecules per formula weight for 2. Contribution of all atoms of the solvent molecules have been incorporated in both the empirical formula and formula weight in Table . Compound 2 did not diffract well at high angles, that is why, in this case, the data completeness was found to be 0.93. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table , while selective bond angles and bond distances are given in Table S1, .

Compounds 1 and 2 are obtained by acidic hydrolysis of ligand 3,5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DBIBN) under solvothermal conditions. The IR spectra of both show strong absorption bands between 1608 and 1454 cm–1 that are diagnostic of coordinated carboxylate groups, and the broad bands in the region 3100–3350 cm–1 indicate the presence of lattice water molecules (Figures S1–S2, ). Compounds once isolated are stable in air and insoluble in common organic solvents and water.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compounds 1 and 2 are obtained by acidic hydrolysis of ligand 3,5-di(1H-benzo[d]imidazol-1-yl)benzonitrile (DBIBN) under solvothermal conditions. The IR spectra of both show strong absorption bands between 1608 and 1454 cm-1 that are diagnostic of coordinated carboxylate groups, and the broad bands in the region 3100-3350 cm-1 indicate the presence of lattice water molecules (Figures S1-S2, ). Compounds once isolated are stable in air and insoluble in common organic solvents and water.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, and hence, the structure of only 1 is discussed here. Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅1c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ni(II) ion with 1/3 occupancy, half ligand (DBIBA–), one chloride ion with 1/6 occupancy, and three lattice water molecules. The structure contains a binuclear Ni(II) unit built through three bridging carboxylates, while the other three coordination sites of each metal ion are occupied by three benzimidazole N atoms forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural, and hence, the structure of only 1 is discussed here. Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅1c. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ni(II) ion with 1/3 occupancy, half ligand (DBIBA-), one chloride ion with 1/6 occupancy, and three lattice water molecules. The structure contains a binuclear Ni(II) unit built through three bridging carboxylates, while the other three coordination sites of each metal ion are occupied by three benzimidazole N atoms forming a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure ).

elements.content: Coordination environment and bond distances around metal center in dimeric unit of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environment and bond distances around metal center in dimeric unit of 1.

elements.content: In the dimeric unit, the two metal ions are 4.106 Å apart. Further, the dimeric units are connected to benzimidazole N atoms to form a chain along the crystallographic a axis (Figure ). Framework is stabilized by hydrogen bonding (2.326(4)–2.864(3) Å), which exists in C5–H5···Cl1, C6–H6···Cl1, C8–H8···O1, and C6–H6···N2 (Figure ).

elements.content: All the bond distances involving the metal ion are found to be within normal statistical errors. When viewed along the c axis, 1D hexagonal channels of diameter ∼6.6 Å (considering the van der Waals radii) can be observed (Figure c). The cavity is decorated with benzimidazole moieties and there are strong π–π interactions between two benzene rings and two imidazole rings of two different ligand moieties (Figure a). Maybe due to this strong π–π interaction, the cavity is rigid in nature. Topological analysis shows that 1 has a 4,6-connected net having point symbol {44.62}3{49.66}2 considering Ni(II) ions as 6-connected nodes and the DBIBA– ligand as a 4-connected node (Figure ). The solvent accessible volume is ∼32% of the unit cell volume, calculated from the crystal structure using the PLATON program.

elements.content: Compound 2 also crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅1c. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) ion with 1/3 occupancy, half ligand (DBIBA–), one chloride ion with 1/6 occupancy, and half lattice water molecule. In complex 2, Mn–N and Mn–O bonds are comparatively longer than complex 1 (Figure ). The distance between two metal ions in the dimeric unit is 4.124 Å. Hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions in hexagonal channels (Figure b) are weak in comparison to complex 1, and the diameter of 1D hexagonal channels is ∼7.1 Å (considering the van der Waals radii). The solvent accessible volume is found to be ∼33.7% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: High thermal stability of 1 and 2 is observed in their thermograms. In the case of 1, a weight-loss of ∼20.6% (expected = 21%) is found in the temperature range 30–400 °C, corresponding to the loss of 18 lattice water molecules in the hexagonal channels (Figure S3, ). While 2 shows a weight-loss of ∼5% (expected = 4.3%) in the range 60–180 °C attributable to the lattice water molecules (Figure S4, ). Decomposition of 1 and 2 can be achieved beyond 410 °C.

elements.content: To evaluate porosity of 1 and 2 as well as their gas adsorption ability, gas adsorption measurements are performed using N2, H2, and CO2 under different experimental conditions. Both 1 and 2 are activated by immersing the crystals in DCM for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM, and after that, it is heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove all solvent molecules. Permanent porosity of 1 and 2 are confirmed by gas sorption measurements at low pressure with N2, H2 at 77 K, and CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K. The BET surface area of 2, calculated from N2 adsorption isotherm, is found to be 359 m2 g–1 with pore volume equal to 0.16 cm3 g–1. Compound 2 shows H2 uptake of 103.8 cm3 g–1 (0.92 wt %) at 1.0 atm with large hysteresis, while no hysteresis is observed for CO2. The maximum CO2 uptake at 1 atm are 160.4, 52.7, and 44.1 cm3 g–1 at 195, 273, and 298 K, respectively (Figure b). However, N2 and H2 do not diffuse into the pores of 1 at 77 K and show only surface adsorption (7.4 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 1.8 cm3 g–1 for H2 at P/P o = 1). Although the channel size is large enough compared to the kinetic diameter of N2 and H2 (3.6 and 2.9 Å, respectively), this may be attributed to the 1D channel systems running along crystallographic c axis (Figure c) in all the frameworks, and there are no additional effective channels that can be observed along the a or b axis. Interestingly, a CO2 adsorption experiment for 1 shows a typical type I adsorption isotherm, confirming the microporous nature of 1. The maximum CO2 uptake at 1 atm for desolvated 1 are 135.4, 50.7, and 44.8 cm3 g–1 at 195, 273, and 298 K, respectively (Figure a). These values for both compounds are moderately high and comparable to the recently reported values. Such selectivity and difference in sorption properties of two isostructural MOFs, 1 and 2, are very uncommon. It is well-known that the flexibility in frameworks, in most cases, causes selective sorption of gases by guest-directed framework rearrangements. However, it could also be possible that flexible framework can rearrange the pore structure in response to guest stimuli having large framework–guest interaction and adsorb gases or molecules of similar sizes without any selectivity. The maintenance of framework integrity was proven by identical PXRD patterns before and after heat treatment for 1 (Figure a). However, for 2, careful examination of PXRD (Figure b) shows slight shifting of peaks toward lower 2θ values after desolvation. Hysteresis obtained in H2 and N2 sorption isotherms, measured at 77 K, confirm the flexible nature of 2. Such desorption kinetics might also be related to the structural features of desolvated 2 with narrow pore apertures, whereas the favored diffusion of the slightly larger CO2 molecules (3.189 Å) at 195 K should be related to both the flexibility of the framework at higher temperatures as well as higher kinetic energy of the CO2 molecules. Gas adsorption properties of complex 3 was previously reported.

elements.content: To calculate the heat of adsorption of CO2 for complexes 1 and 2, the data are fitted using the Langmuir–Freundlich equation (Figures S5–S6, ). Adsorption enthalpies of the CO2 adsorption are calculated using a variant of the Clausius–Clapeyron equation (Figure ). Heat of adsorption measurements show that 1 has initial affinity of 16.1 kJ/mol, whereas for 2, it is 12.7 kJ/mol calculated at 273 and 298 K.

elements.content: Isostructural complexes 1, 2, and 3 have dinuclear units bridged by three syn–syn carboxylate groups with a distorted configuration having torsion angles N2–M1(Ni, Mn, and Co)–O1–C1 of 52°, 64°, and 60° respectively, for 1, 2, and 3. The lack of planarity will affect the superexchange through the delocalized π-orbitals of the carboxylate group, making it less effective. The dinuclear units are linked in chains by meta-bis-imidazole phenyl groups (Figure ). It is known that this type of meta-substituted phenyl ring leads to weak ferromagnetic coupling. Each one of these chains is a node in a hexagonal network. and these chains are bridged by the ligand. which is meta-substituted by two benzimidazoles and one carboxylate group. Magnetic susceptibility data at an applied dc field of 0.3 T were collected in the 2–300 K temperature range and at an applied field of 200 G below 20 K. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility for 1, 2, and 3 are shown in Figure (see also Figure S7, ). At 300 K, the χ T product has values of 2.37, 8.64, and 6.97 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, 2, and 3 respectively. The values observed for 1 and 2 are in agreement with the expected values for two noninteracting metal ions with g = 2.1 and S = 1 for Ni(II) and g = 2.0 and S = 5/2 for Mn(II). The χT observed for 3 reflects spin–orbit coupling of octahedrally coordinated Co(II). As the temperature decreases, the χT product decreases slightly for all three complexes, due to the Boltzmann depopulation of the excited states and population of the ground state, indicating predominant antiferromagnetic coupling. A sharp increase is observed below 50 K for all three compounds, which is field dependent. This indicates the onset of a weakly ferromagnetic state caused by spin-canting, the order is stronger in 1 due to the largest single ion anisotropy of Ni(II) compared to other metal ions. Recently, magnetic properties have been studied in three isostructural coordination polymers, all showing different kinds of interactions. The spin-canting causes the noncompensation of the spins along the chains, and these are then ferromagnetically coupled in the 3D structure by the meta-substituted aromatic ligands. For 3, one must also take into account the spin–orbit coupling; thus, the situation involves the population of the effective S = 1/2 state for each Co(II) ion at low temperatures and the interaction between the ions; that is why a rise in χT at low temperature is less pronounced. A Curie plot (Figure ) clearly shows the change of slope, a high temperature region above 50 K where the antiferromagnetic coupling dominates, and a lower temperature region where spin-canting causes weak ferromagnetic order.

Magnetic Studies

Isostructural complexes 1, 2, and 3 have dinuclear units bridged by three syn-syn carboxylate groups with a distorted configuration having torsion angles N2-M1(Ni, Mn, and Co)-O1-C1 of 52°, 64°, and 60° respectively, for 1, 2, and 3. The lack of planarity will affect the superexchange through the delocalized π-orbitals of the carboxylate group, making it less effective. The dinuclear units are linked in chains by meta-bis-imidazole phenyl groups (Figure ). It is known that this type of meta-substituted phenyl ring leads to weak ferromagnetic coupling. Each one of these chains is a node in a hexagonal network. and these chains are bridged by the ligand. which is meta-substituted by two benzimidazoles and one carboxylate group. Magnetic susceptibility data at an applied dc field of 0.3 T were collected in the 2-300 K temperature range and at an applied field of 200 G below 20 K. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility for 1, 2, and 3 are shown in Figure  (see also Figure S7, ). At 300 K, the χ T product has values of 2.37, 8.64, and 6.97 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, 2, and 3 respectively. The values observed for 1 and 2 are in agreement with the expected values for two noninteracting metal ions with g = 2.1 and S = 1 for Ni(II) and g = 2.0 and S = 5/2 for Mn(II). The χT observed for 3 reflects spin-orbit coupling of octahedrally coordinated Co(II). As the temperature decreases, the χT product decreases slightly for all three complexes, due to the Boltzmann depopulation of the excited states and population of the ground state, indicating predominant antiferromagnetic coupling. A sharp increase is observed below 50 K for all three compounds, which is field dependent. This indicates the onset of a weakly ferromagnetic state caused by spin-canting, the order is stronger in 1 due to the largest single ion anisotropy of Ni(II) compared to other metal ions. Recently, magnetic properties have been studied in three isostructural coordination polymers, all showing different kinds of interactions. The spin-canting causes the noncompensation of the spins along the chains, and these are then ferromagnetically coupled in the 3D structure by the meta-substituted aromatic ligands. For 3, one must also take into account the spin-orbit coupling; thus, the situation involves the population of the effective S = 1/2 state for each Co(II) ion at low temperatures and the interaction between the ions; that is why a rise in χT at low temperature is less pronounced. A Curie plot (Figure ) clearly shows the change of slope, a high temperature region above 50 K where the antiferromagnetic coupling dominates, and a lower temperature region where spin-canting causes weak ferromagnetic order.

elements.content: The region of temperatures above 50 K can be fitted to the Curie–Weiss law to give Curie constants of 2.98, 9.38, and 8.41 cm3 mol–1 for complexes 1, 2, and 3 and Weiss constants of Θ = −26.69, −24.76, and −60.40 K for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. Negative Weiss constant values indicate predominantly antiferromagnetic coupling down to this temperature. In the magnetization vs field plots (Figure ), one can see how the saturation values at 2 K are well below that expected for 1, 2, and 3 and never going above 2 Bohr magnetons, in agreement with a canted antiferromagnet. The ac measurements for 2 showed no out-of-phase signal, while ac measurements for complexes 1 and 3 at 10 and 990 Hz ac oscillating fields (Figures S8–S9, ) displayed a peak to be out-of-phase at 15 K for 1 and 8 K for 3, indicating the ordering temperature due to anisotropy of Ni(II) and Co(II).

elements.content: In this article, two new isostructural 3D microporous coordination polymers have been synthesized with DBIBN ligand under in situ cyanide hydrolysis. Compound 1 exhibits selective adsorption–desorption of CO2 at low pressure, while compound 2 shows adsorption of N2, H2, and CO2 at low pressure without having any selectivity. Both 1 and 2 shows weak ferromagnetic properties due to spin canting. Although, both complexes have the same framework structure, but their gas adsorption and magnetic properties are very different with 1 showing a rigid, and 2, a flexibile framework. Conclusively, we can say rigid pores appear to be available for gas storage application, while dynamic pores are difficult to characterize, so there is no more selectivity. Future coordination polymers incorporating different structural properties are in progress with other transition and lanthanide metals in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this article, two new isostructural 3D microporous coordination polymers have been synthesized with DBIBN ligand under in situ cyanide hydrolysis. Compound 1 exhibits selective adsorption-desorption of CO2 at low pressure, while compound 2 shows adsorption of N2, H2, and CO2 at low pressure without having any selectivity. Both 1 and 2 shows weak ferromagnetic properties due to spin canting. Although, both complexes have the same framework structure, but their gas adsorption and magnetic properties are very different with 1 showing a rigid, and 2, a flexibile framework. Conclusively, we can say rigid pores appear to be available for gas storage application, while dynamic pores are difficult to characterize, so there is no more selectivity. Future coordination polymers incorporating different structural properties are in progress with other transition and lanthanide metals in our laboratory.

This ligand was synthesized as previously reported.

Synthesis of {[Ni<sub>2</sub>(DBIBA)<sub>3</sub>]·Cl·18H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.07 g, 0.24 mmol), DBIBN (0.04 g, 0.12 mmol), and conc. HCl (0.1 mL) in EtOH:H2O (3 mL, 2:1 v/v) were placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Then, it was allowed to cool to room temperature at the rate of 1 °C/min. Needle-shaped green crystals of 1 were collected in ∼42% yield. The crystals were repeatedly washed with ethanol and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C63H75N12O24ClNi2: C, 49.22; H, 4.92; N, 10.93%. Found: C, 49.07; H, 4.35; N, 10.82%. IR (cm–1): 3394(m), 3141(w), 3074(w), 3000(w), 1650(m), 1598(s), 1503(s), 1474(m), 1451(w), 1401(s), 1372(m), 1307(m), 1292(m), 1242(s), 1222(w), 1172(w), 1148(w), 1107(w), 1011(w), 942(w), 910(w), 861(w), 795(w), 778(m), 765(m), 746(s), 724(m), 693(w), 649(w), 627(w), 613(w), 525(w), 439(w), 425(w) (Figure S1, ).

Synthesis of {[Mn<sub>2</sub>(DBIBA)<sub>3</sub>]·Cl·3H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

This compound was synthesized in the same way as described for 1 except that Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (0.06 g, 0.24 mmol) was used in place of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. Needle-shaped brown crystals of 2 were collected in ∼38% yield. The crystals were repeatedly washed with ethanol and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C63H45N12O9ClMn2: C, 60.08; H, 3.60; N, 13.35%. Found: C, 59.80; H, 3.82; N, 13.90%. IR (cm–1): 3382(w), 3057(w), 3003(w), 1911(w), 1643(m), 1586(s), 1502(s), 1452(m), 1404(s), 1375(m), 1294(m), 1242(s), 1222(m), 1173(w), 1149(w), 1110(w), 1011(w), 940(w), 906(w), 875(w), 864(w), 795(w), 782(m), 764(m), 744(s), 720(m), 693(w), 646(w), 625(w), 611(w), 560(w), 519(w), 429(w) (Figure S2, ). Interestingly, a different coordination polymer is formed when the hydrolysis is carried out with Et3N.

cln_elements.content:
High thermal stability of 1 and 2 is observed in their thermograms. In the case of 1, a weight-loss of ∼20.6% (expected = 21%) is found in the temperature range 30–400 °C, corresponding to the loss of 18 lattice water molecules in the hexagonal channels (Figure S3, ). While 2 shows a weight-loss of ∼5% (expected = 4.3%) in the range 60–180 °C attributable to the lattice water molecules (Figure S4, ). Decomposition of 1 and 2 can be achieved beyond 410 °C.

Gas Adsorption Studies

To evaluate porosity of 1 and 2 as well as their gas adsorption ability, gas adsorption measurements are performed using N2, H2, and CO2 under different experimental conditions. Both 1 and 2 are activated by immersing the crystals in DCM for 3 days at room temperature to replace guest molecules from the lattice by DCM, and after that, it is heated to 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum to remove all solvent molecules. Permanent porosity of 1 and 2 are confirmed by gas sorption measurements at low pressure with N2, H2 at 77 K, and CO2 at 195, 273, and 298 K. The BET surface area of 2, calculated from N2 adsorption isotherm, is found to be 359 m2 g–1 with pore volume equal to 0.16 cm3 g–1. Compound 2 shows H2 uptake of 103.8 cm3 g–1 (0.92 wt %) at 1.0 atm with large hysteresis, while no hysteresis is observed for CO2. The maximum CO2 uptake at 1 atm are 160.4, 52.7, and 44.1 cm3 g–1 at 195, 273, and 298 K, respectively (Figure b). However, N2 and H2 do not diffuse into the pores of 1 at 77 K and show only surface adsorption (7.4 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 1.8 cm3 g–1 for H2 at P/P o = 1). Although the channel size is large enough compared to the kinetic diameter of N2 and H2 (3.6 and 2.9 Å, respectively), this may be attributed to the 1D channel systems running along crystallographic c axis (Figure c) in all the frameworks, and there are no additional effective channels that can be observed along the a or b axis. Interestingly, a CO2 adsorption experiment for 1 shows a typical type I adsorption isotherm, confirming the microporous nature of 1. The maximum CO2 uptake at 1 atm for desolvated 1 are 135.4, 50.7, and 44.8 cm3 g–1 at 195, 273, and 298 K, respectively (Figure a). These values for both compounds are moderately high and comparable to the recently reported values. Such selectivity and difference in sorption properties of two isostructural MOFs, 1 and 2, are very uncommon. It is well-known that the flexibility in frameworks, in most cases, causes selective sorption of gases by guest-directed framework rearrangements. However, it could also be possible that flexible framework can rearrange the pore structure in response to guest stimuli having large framework–guest interaction and adsorb gases or molecules of similar sizes without any selectivity. The maintenance of framework integrity was proven by identical PXRD patterns before and after heat treatment for 1 (Figure a). However, for 2, careful examination of PXRD (Figure b) shows slight shifting of peaks toward lower 2θ values after desolvation. Hysteresis obtained in H2 and N2 sorption isotherms, measured at 77 K, confirm the flexible nature of 2. Such desorption kinetics might also be related to the structural features of desolvated 2 with narrow pore apertures, whereas the favored diffusion of the slightly larger CO2 molecules (3.189 Å) at 195 K should be related to both the flexibility of the framework at higher temperatures as well as higher kinetic energy of the CO2 molecules. Gas adsorption properties of complex 3 was previously reported.
